---
title: "Visualizing_the_data"
output: html_document
date: "2023-09-12"
---

```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
```

```{r}
# Loading in packages
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

# Creating the dataset

urls = c('http://data.insideairbnb.com/the-netherlands/north-holland/amsterdam/2023-09-03/data/listings.csv.gz', 'http://data.insideairbnb.com/the-netherlands/north-holland/amsterdam/2023-09-03/data/calendar.csv.gz', 'http://data.insideairbnb.com/the-netherlands/north-holland/amsterdam/2023-09-03/data/reviews.csv.gz')

airbnb_amsterdam <- lapply(urls, read_csv, n_max = Inf)

# combine rows in data
combined_airbnb_amsterdam <- bind_rows(airbnb_amsterdam)
view(combined_airbnb_amsterdam)

# explore
view(combined_airbnb_amsterdam)
summary(combined_airbnb_amsterdam)

# visualization
ggplot()

```


## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
